abstract.p: L L Bean sporting goods center in Freeport, Me, plans to open outdoor adventure center, where customers will be able to try out equipment (and the sport) before investing in gear (S)

block.p: L. L. Bean in Freeport, Me., has long been a destination for those in search of everything from a fishing rod to flannel sheets. Now, the 95-year-old retailer has plans to lure sports enthusiasts with a nearby outdoor adventure center, where customers will actually be able to try out the equipment (and the sport) before investing in the gear.
''A kayak is a small amount of money, but it is still nice to try the equipment and have some instruction before you actually make the purchase,'' said Carolyn Beem, a spokeswoman for the company.

Now, the 95-year-old retailer has plans to lure sports enthusiasts with a nearby outdoor adventure center, where customers will actually be able to try out the equipment (and the sport) before investing in the gear.
''A kayak is a small amount of money, but it is still nice to try the equipment and have some instruction before you actually make the purchase,'' said Carolyn Beem, a spokeswoman for the company.

The plan, still preliminary, calls for cross-country skiing, a pond for fly-fishing, and a climbing wall, as well as hiking trails on a 700-acre site located a mile from the main store, Ms. Beem said.
